Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant will fund two related conferences aimed at addressing gender imbalances within the mathematical sciences. The first conference is a weekend long conference for women undergraduates in the mathematical science, designed to encourage women studying mathematics in the USA to continue their mathematical education at the graduate level. The second activity is a summit of mathematicians, with the goal of addressing the broader issues that affect the gender imbalances in the mathematical sciences.

The undergraduate conference, titled Graduate Research Opportunities for Women (GROW) is modeled on the first such conference organized at Northwestern in October 2015, which attracted 50 undergraduates from across the mathematical sciences and a wide variety of institutions, and will bring together 80 women undergraduates interested in pure and applied mathematics. As in the first iteration, GROW II will combine research talks, panel discussions, mentoring in groups and individually, a banquet with speech by a keynote speaker, and networking opportunities. We will also create a framework for this activity to continue into the future, not only at Northwestern but also at other institutions. The second activity is a meeting of mathematicians in the two days before the next incarnation of GROW. This summit will discuss ways in which the US mathematics major can be recrafted to make it more attractive to undergraduate women; reasons behind the substantial differences in gender ratio among mathematics majors at different colleges and universities in the USA; and the creation of a network of ambassadors who will be able to assist people at other locations around the country to implement similar programs. This work is co-funded by the NSF's Division of Mathematical Sciences and the Division of Undergraduate Education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to understand the reasons behind the gender imbalances in mathematics and to encourage talented women studying mathematics in the USA to continue their mathematical education at the graduate level.   To achieve this, we ran a major conference, GROW 2016 (Graduate Research Opportunities for Women), over a weekend in October, 2016.  This conference included 80 undergraduate participants interested in pure and applied mathematics and involved over 40 mentors drawn from faculty and graduate students.  Activities included three research talks, tone even address, three panels (on research in mathematics, careers in academic, and on applying to graduate school), and numerous opportunities for networking and mentoring.  

 

We also ran a Summit Meeting on Gender Imbalances in Mathematics during the two days preceding the GROW conference (some of the participants stayed for GROW and participated as panelists and mentors). This meeting included 18 participants from across the country and numerous local participants.  The summary report for this meeting is available on the conference website.

 

We continue to survey the students who participated, connecting them with mentors across the country and following their progress as they enroll in graduate school.  The conference has been replicated elsewhere and the series of GROW conferences continues to run at other institutions.
